citation.article-title: Reclassification of Myxococcus flavescens Yamanaka et al. 1990 as a later synonym of Myxococcus virescens Thaxter 1892AL.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Emended description of Myxococcus virescens Thaxter 1892 (Approved Lists 1980)
Myxococcus virescens (vi.res′cens. L. part. adj. virescens becoming green).
Vegetative cells are slender rods with short tapering ends, cigar-shaped, 0.7–0.8×4–8 μm.

Fruiting bodies are globular or oval, and rarely even finger-like; on agar media plump ridges and, very often, a deliquescent mound are observed; typically greenish yellow in colour, but often yellow–orange, and even non-pigmented (grey).
Fruiting bodies can be large, 150–500 μm.
Myxospores are spherical, optically refractile and very large [1.9–2.4 μm in diameter (range 1.7–2.6 μm)], with a thick capsule.
Their large size is the most reliable distinguishing characteristic for the species.
Characteristic of the family, swarm colonies are non-pigmented or greenish yellow, or sometimes orange.
Temperature and pH ranges and nutritional requirement are as for the other species of the genus.
Positive for hydrolysis of casein, DNA and starch.
Negative for hydrolysis of starch, aesculin and xylan, when tested on overlay agar after 4–5 days.

Major fatty acids are iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 1ω5c and iso-C17 : 0 whereas C14 : 0, C15 : 0, iso-C14 : 0 3-OH, anteiso-C17 : 1 and/or iso-C17:1 and an unknown fatty acid with ECL 14.959 occur in smaller amounts.
Common organisms in soil, in rotting plant material and in samples from the littoral region; easily obtained when rabbit or sheep dung is incubated in a moist chamber.
The DNA G+C content is 68–71 % (buoyant density; Tm).
